intro: There’s a reason Asian Americans, like Haimei, get so excited when we see ourselves represented: For much of US history, Asian American characters in popular media were meant to mock us. The early 1900s saw white actors donning [“yellowface”](https://www.history.com/news/yellowface-whitewashing-in-film-america) to play some of the most prominent Asian characters, including Charlie Chan, Dr. Fu Manchu and Mr. Yunioshi. Exaggerated racial features—including slanted eyes, yellow skin color, black hair, and an “Asian” accent—were common. >> Breakfast_at_Mr_Yunioshis.gif | Breakfast_at_Mr_Yunioshis.gif | Mickey Rooney plays Mr. Yunioshi in yellowface | Mickey Rooney plays Mr. Yunioshi in Breakfast at Tiffany's (1961) Source: GifRun When Asian American actors were finally cast to play Asian characters, they were often portrayed through stereotypes, like Bruce Lee being confined to martial arts roles or Nancy Kwan repeatedly cast as a “Dragon Lady.” >> nancy-kwan.png | nancy-kwan.png | Nancy Kwan plays Suzie Wong in The World of Suzie Wong (1960) | Nancy Kwan plays Suzie Wong in The World of Suzie Wong (1960) But these days, Asian actors no longer play stereotypes; they are full characters—love interests, superheroes, and even the modern-day American family. Yet there’s more to it than just portraying characters. Asian Americans come from dozens of countries with even more unique ethnic identities. When the characters inaccurately portray those aspects of our identity, we notice. And it’s not just us. A [study published in 2025](https://www.mckinsey.com/featured-insights/diversity-and-inclusion/from-margins-to-mainstream-asians-and-pacific-islanders-in-hollywood) showed that less than 30% of Asian and Pacific Islanders feel like they are represented in the media. That’s partially because, according to a [2023 poll by the Pew Research Center](https://www.pewresearch.org/race-and-ethnicity/2023/05/08/diverse-cultures-and-shared-experiences-shape-asian-american-identities/), many Asian Americans feel more closely aligned with their specific ethnicity, like “Chinese” or “Thai,” rather than broadly “Asian.” So it’s especially exciting to see our specific customs, cuisines, and languages reflected on the big screen. >> ChartAAPI.svg | ChartAAPI-mobile.svg | How Asian Americans identify themselves | Data source: Pew Research Center, Survey of Asian American adults conducted 2022 - 2023 | How Asian Americans identify themselves It’s difficult to judge whether a character fairly portrays a specific ethnicity, but we can assess whether an actor and the character they portray share the same ethnicity as a baseline for accurate representation. To explore this actor-character mismatch further, we compiled more than 3,500 films from 1982 to 2023 featuring Asian actors. We identified films where Asian actors played a major role, getting us to 500 films. From there, we filtered the list down to films where the character’s Asian ethnicity was a notable part of the storyline; we wanted to focus on media where we were supposed to feel represented but didn’t due to these inaccuracies. For example, *The Life of Pi (2012)* qualified because the protagonist, Pi, struggles with his Hindu faith and Indian heritage along with other reflections. However, *Jumanji: The Next Level (2019)* did not; while the character Dr. Bravestone is played by Samoan actor Dwayne “The Rock” Johnson, the plot does not reference the character’s Asian identity at all. Ultimately we found **80 films** with **160 Asian actors** playing **236 characters**. While we covered a wide breadth of movies, our criteria for including movies was based on having high profile actors in the cast or reaching a moderate threshold for box office earnings, so it’s possible we missed some movies.

start.text: The first thing we noticed in our data is that Asian representation really has increased in the past few decades! The 1980s marked an important breakthrough when films like Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom (1984) starred child actor Ke Huy Quan alongside some of Hollywood’s biggest names.

Then came The Joy Luck Club (1993), a landmark movie that was the first to feature a majority Asian American cast. The movie follows four Chinese American mothers and daughters, highlighting the complexities of immigration. This film launched the careers of several Asian actors. Ming-Na Wen, who plays June, said the film was her [“green card to Hollywood.”](https://www.nytimes.com/2018/09/09/movies/joy-luck-club-crazy-rich-asians.html) But director Wayne Wang struggled to gain momentum in directing more Asian-centered stories, and it would be decades before we would see another major film with a large Asian cast.

Starting in the late-1990s, movies like Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon (2000) brought Asian stories to mainstream audiences. Actors like Michelle Yeoh, Jackie Chan, and Tony Leung Chiu-wai began to build prominent, international careers. For the first time, a surge of Asian stars was driving significant box office success.
Many Asian main characters were still confined to stereotypes, such as Jackie Chan being a martial artist in Rush Hour (1998) or the “oriental” women in Memoirs of a Geisha (2005).

In the 2010s, we started to see Asian characters in varying roles with more in-depth characterization. From 2007 to 2022, the percentage of Asian characters with speaking roles [increased from 3.4% to 15.9%](https://time.com/6305012/hollywood-diversity-report-asian-representation/), the largest increase among any racial group during that time.
Recent films like Shang-Chi and the Legend of the Ten Rings (2021) and Joy Ride (2023) have highlighted a diverse set of stories across all genres.

middle: This new era of Asian representation has been further cemented by the widespread success of movies like *Crazy Rich Asians (2018)*, *Minari (2020)*, and *Everything Everywhere All At Once (2022)*. >> crazy-rich-asians-gif.gif | crazy-rich-asians-gif.gif | The cast receiving award | The cast of Crazy Rich Asians (2018) at the Screen Actors Guild Awards. Source: Giphy But despite all of this recognition, that gets us back to Haimei’s original complaint: How common is it for Asian characters to be played by an actor of a different ethnicity? When we first broached this question, we immediately thought of several examples we'd seen on television. In *Fresh Off the Boat*, Korean actor Randall Park plays a Chinese character. In *Kim’s Convenience*, Chinese actor Simu Liu plays a Korean character. So, honestly, we expected to find a plethora of mismatches.

end.text: We started with the **80 films** and **236 characters** in our dataset.
Out of 80 movies we looked at, **64** were cast with complete accuracy.
Meanwhile, **13** movies were cast with partial accuracy.

And only **3** out of the 80 movies were cast completely inaccurately. These three films were more obscure—and chances are, you’ve never even heard of them, like *Missing in Action (1984)* or* A Hologram for the King (2016)*.

Notably, it’s not an Asian actor’s fault that they are playing a character of a different ethnicity. In the past, being Asian greatly limited the types of roles available in Hollywood, so actors had to take what was available to them in a white-centric industry.

On a character level, 207 out of 236 Asian main characters—**88%**—were portrayed by actors of the same ethnic background. This was more accurate than we’d expected! We were ready to blame Hollywood, but it looks like casting directors have been paying attention to Asian actors’ ethnicities.

That said, some factors that influenced accurate—and inaccurate—casting. 


For example, the **“Big Five” production studios**—Universal, Paramount, Warner Bros., Disney, and Sony—control nearly 85% of the movie market share. With more resources, these large studios have the means to reach mainstream audiences and feature bigger stars.


But they were responsible for just **39%** of the 80 movies.

Still, “Big Five” studios are behind some of the most celebrated films with Asian characters, including Crazy Rich Asians (2018) and Shang-Chi and the Legend of the Ten Rings (2021). And they do a fairly accurate job of casting—about **84%**, slightly below overall casting accuracy.

Meanwhile, movies with **Asian directors** had a **94%** accuracy rate, well above the 83% average for non-Asian directors.


It’s clear that when Asian filmmakers get the opportunity to make movies, casting is done with more intentionality and accuracy.

Asian directors have also recently begun receiving more recognition, with Everything Everywhere All At Once (2022) director Daniel Kwan becoming the first Asian director to win the Oscar for Best Director for an Asian-led film.
**Explore these films by interacting with the chart.**

conclusion:
This project was prompted by the disheartening experiences we’ve had watching miscast characters in popular media, so we came into this project expecting more miscastings than not. When our analysis found that most films were accurately cast, it was unexpected and empowering!


But we know how fragile this progress can be. In 2024, racial and gender diversity in Hollywood [decreased for the first time in six years](https://newsroom.ucla.edu/releases/hollywood-diversity-in-decline-as-moviegoers-worldwide-want-more), part of a larger social regression. In a [recent interview](https://www.nbcnews.com/news/asian-america/constance-wu-the-friend-movie-hollywood-diversity-rcna198408), Constance Wu said that she’s noticed that representation is becoming less important in casting. She said this could be a sign of people in Hollywood “reverting to limited imaginations of what story and characters could be.”


We’re worried about what we might be losing.


Whether it’s seeing my (Dorothy) family’s breakfast traditions reflected in *Shang-Chi and the Legend of the Ten Rings (2021)* or watching *Didi (2024)* and commiserating with friends about growing up in immigrant households, these movies have made us feel seen. It’s the subtleties of everyday interactions that resonate with us, not the flashy shows of “representation.” 


When I call my mom while trying to recreate the recipes of my childhood or realize my Shanghainese is fading because I only speak it with family, it’s easy to feel isolated in the struggle to balance my Chinese and American identities. 


But seeing those experiences represented on the big screen serve as a powerful affirmation that I am not alone—and that my experiences are worth being shared and truly understood.
methodology:
Our initial datasets started with [Luminate](https://luminatedata.com/), a database for music and entertainment data that was previously part of Nielsen Media Research. We used this database to find every film featuring a popular Asian actor since 1981. Luminate Data includes information on actors' backgrounds and ethnicities, movies they were in, and details about each movie. 


Using the advanced search feature, we compiled a list of “Asian Lead Cast” actors that were in production films released in theaters between 1981 and 2023. We then put together a list of all the movies these actors were in, given that the movie originated from the United States and was not a documentary or animated movie.


Our initial list was too broad since it included actors who were solely in films that were not widely distributed. So we filtered the data based on a metric called ScreenScore—a 1-100 scoring system that measures the popularity and relevance of each actor. It considers factors such as how often the actor is searched, the significance of movies they’ve been in, and any awards they’ve received. We talked to a representative at Luminate who helped us determine that a score of 60 was a reasonable cutoff. This left us with 83 actors.


We identified all the movies where these 83 actors were a “Main Title Actor,” meaning they had a significant role in the film. We filtered out movies that had a box office debut of less than 1,000,000 USD, resulting in 371 movies.


We wanted to make sure we didn’t miss any major films. So we added films with Asian actors from the [top-50 highest-grossing films](https://www.boxofficemojo.com/year/2025/) each year, according to IMDB. This gave us **3,582 films**. Of these 2,150 movies, there were 96 movies that ChatGPT classified as having at least one Asian main character that we then added to our list of movies, bringing it to **467 movies.** 


We then needed to identify the movies that not only had Asian main actors, but also storylines where Asian characters had ethnicities that mattered. While inherently a subjective process, we considered factors such as characters speaking Asian languages, embodying Asian family structures, participating in cultural or religious activities, or storylines based in Asian history. We also referenced actor interviews, movie transcripts, online articles, and also used our best judgment to try and categorize these films.


This brought our list from 467 to **80 movies**—a huge filtering of our list, but this just goes to show that while a large number of films had Asian actors, most character’s ethnicities were not relevant to the plot.


Our final dataset included **236 Asian characters** in the **80 films** played by **160 unique actors.** 


We needed to find the ethnicity of the actor and compare that to the ethnicity of their characters. We started with actor profiles in Luminate, which had actor ethnicities and nationalities. For the few Luminate profiles that didn’t have actor ethnicities, we looked at Wikipedia, interviews, and other online articles. 


To determine character ethnicity, we looked at movie transcripts and third party journalism. When character ethnicity was not explicit, we inferred based on family members, surnames, and plot context. There were some characters that did not have enough context to determine their ethnicity, so we removed them from the dataset. 


If an actor had at least a partial ethnicity match with a character they played, we considered that a match. There were 11 characters across six movies who we could not determine a specific ethnicity for a character, so we removed them from our data.
